params.text:
• Quickly locate key words in a document
  • Recognize transparent words
  • Identify and extract the ideas giving meaning to the text

Reading

Improve Reading and Comprehension Strategies

Language in Action
Reading: Introduction

Ready to unlock the secrets of any text? This module equips you with essential skills to become a confident and successful reader.

Here's what you'll explore:

1. Finding Key Words: Learn strategies to quickly locate the most important words that hold the meaning of a passage.

  2. Transparent Words: Discover how to recognize words that are similar to your own language, making reading easier!

  3. Extracting Ideas: Master the art of identifying the main points and central ideas within a text.
Quickly Locate Key Words In A Document: Key Points

Finding the important words in a text is like finding hidden treasure! 

Here are some tips to be a keyword ninja:
Titles & Headings:

• Titles and headings are like treasure maps - they give you clues about the main ideas. Look at the title and any headings within the text to get a general idea of the topic and what keywords you might find.
Bold & Italics:
First & Last Sentences:
Think Like a Detective:
• Sometimes, important words are like flashing neon signs - they're bold or italicized to stand out. Scan the text for these highlighted words, as they're likely to be key!
• The first sentence of a paragraph often introduces the main idea, and the last sentence might summarize it. So, these are good places to hunt for keywords related to that paragraph's topic.

• What is the text about? Put yourself in the detective's shoes and ask yourself: What are the most important things the author wants me to know? The words that answer those questions are likely your keywords.
Quickly Locate Key Words In A Document - Forum & Quiz
You are reading an online forum about learning Spanish. Please read the posts, and answer the questions below:

choices.question: Question 1 of 2: Abigail says titles are helpful when finding keywords. Why are titles useful?
answers:
Titles give clues about the main topic and what keywords to look for. 

Titles are always long and contain many details. 

Titles tell a story and entertain the reader.

choices.question:
Question 2 of 2: Bryan suggests looking at the first sentence to find keywords in an email.
Why might the first sentence be helpful?
answers:
It often introduces the main topic of the email. 

It contains the sender's name and greeting.

params.text: Abigail:
Micah:
Abigail: "Titles are my best friends! Before I start reading everything, I look at the title to see what the text is about. This helps me guess what kind of keywords I should be looking for."
Micah: "Bold words shine out! I always scan for bold or italicized words because they're likely to be important and help me understand the main idea."

Bryan: "When I read an email, the first sentence is like a mini-introduction! It often tells me what the email is about. So I always pay close attention to the first sentence to find keywords about the topic."
Bryan:

choices.question:
Question 1 of 4: You see the heading "Benefits of Fruits and Vegetables."
What kind of keywords might you find under this heading?
answers:
Words related to vitamins, minerals, and health benefits. 

Words related to different cooking methods and recipes. 

Words related to the history of agriculture and farming.

choices.question: Question 2 of 4: You're scanning the text and see the sentence in bold: "Sugary drinks are a major source of empty calories." Why might this sentence be bold?
answers:
It highlights an important point about healthy eating. 

It asks a question that the text will answer later. 

It introduces a new character in the story. 

It describes the appearance of a healthy meal.

choices.question: Question 3 of 4: You've finished reading the first paragraph and wonder what the keywords might be. What can you do to help you identify them?
answers:
Think about the main idea of healthy eating and see which words in the paragraph relate to that. 

Skip to the last sentence of the text and start there. 

Reread the entire paragraph several times.

choices.question: Question 4 of 4: You're reading an email about a meeting about a new project. The first sentence says: "Let's meet tomorrow to discuss the marketing plan for the new product launch." What keywords might be helpful to understand the email?
answers:
Meeting, marketing plan, new product launch. 

Time, location, attendees of the meeting. 

Thank you, best regards, closing salutation.

params.text: What Would You Say? Quiz

Imagine you're reading a short text about "Healthy Eating."
Answer the following questions!
Recognize Transparent Words: Key Points

Have you ever noticed words in English that look familiar to your own language? These are called "transparent words," and they're like secret weapons to unlock your reading comprehension! 

Here's how to recognize them:

• Many English words share common roots or structures with words in other languages.
    For example, "navigation" (English) and "navigazione" (Italian) both have to do with steering or finding your way.
Look for Similarities:
Pay Attention to Prefixes & Suffixes:
Use Context Clues:

• English uses prefixes (added to the beginning of a word) and suffixes (added to the end) to change a word's meaning. If you recognize these parts, you can often guess the meaning of the whole word. For instance, "re-" often means "again" (reheat, restart), and "-able" means "can be done" (readable, comfortable).

• Sometimes, even if you don't recognize a transparent word at first, the surrounding words and sentences can help you figure it out. For example, in the sentence "The renovation project will take several months," you might not know "renovation" but can guess it has something to do with fixing or changing something based on the context.

choices.question:
Question 1 of 3: Abigail is having trouble understanding some words in an article.
What does Micah suggest to help her?
answers:
Look for words that resemble words she knows in her own language. 

Skip the words she doesn't understand and keep reading. 

Memorize a list of difficult words from the article.

choices.question:
Question 2 of 3: Micah gives the example of the word "environmental."
Why might this word be considered transparent for Abigail?
answers:
It shares similarities with a Spanish word. 

It's a very short word and easy to remember. 

It's a common word used in everyday conversations.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: Based on the conversation, what can Abigail do to improve her understanding of difficult words?
answers:
Focus on memorizing the prefixes and suffixes of the words.

Look for other words in the text that might be transparent based on her language. 

Reread the entire article several times to see if she understands it better.

params.text: Recognize Transparent Words: Conversation and Quiz
Please listen to the conversation between Abigail and Micah, and answer the questions below:
Micah:
Abigail:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Dialogue Text 1:

Abigail: I'm reading this article about climate change, but there are some big words I don't understand.

Micah: That can be tricky. But sometimes there are words that look familiar to our own language! English has a lot of words similar to Spanish, for example.

Abigail: Really? Like what?

Micah: Well, look at this sentence: "The pollution from factories is a major environmental problem." Do you recognize "environmental"?

Abigail: Maybe it's related to a similar word in Spanish?
2:

Micah: Exactly! And "pollution" sounds similar too, right? These are transparent words! They share a common base with Spanish words, so they're easier to understand.

Abigail: Wow, that's helpful! So, if I see a word that looks familiar, I can try to guess its meaning based on a Spanish word I know?

Micah: That's a great strategy! Plus, the text around the word can also give you clues about its meaning.

Abigail: Thanks! This will help me understand more difficult words.
Recognize Transparent Words - Sentences

params.text: Identify And Extract The Ideas Giving Meaning To The Text

Ever feel like you've read a text, but you're not sure what the main point is? 
Don't worry, here  are some strategies to help you identify and extract the central ideas:

• Titles and headings are like flashing neon signs - they highlight the main topics and ideas within the text. Pay close attention to them!
    Example: Reading a business report titled "Sales Report for Q1 2024" tells you the main focus is on sales figures for the first quarter of the year.
Focus on the Title & Headings:
Look for the "Who, What, When, Where, Why & How":
Identify the First & Last Sentences:

• Just like in detective work, asking yourself these questions can help you gather clues about the main idea.
  • Who: Who is the text about? (e.g., A new company policy)
  • What: What is the main topic or event? (e.g., Introduction of a new product line)
  • When: When does the text take place? (e.g., Deadline for submitting project proposals)
  • Where: Where does the text refer to? (e.g., Location of the upcoming sales conference)
  • Why: Why is this information important? (e.g., Reasons for a change in company procedures)
  • How: How is something done or achieved? (e.g., Steps to follow when requesting a leave of absence)

• The first sentence of a paragraph often introduces the main idea, and the last sentence might summarize it. So, these are prime locations to hunt for clues!
    Example: "The marketing team has developed a new advertising campaign to target a younger demographic. The campaign will utilize social media platforms and influencer partnerships to reach this audience effectively." (First sentence introduces the main idea - new marketing campaign, last sentence summarizes the methods used

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: Bryan is having trouble understanding the main points of a memo. What does Anthony suggest he do?
answers:
Use detective skills to identify key clues within the text. 

Skip the memo and ask someone to explain it to him. 

Memorize all the information mentioned in the memo.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: Anthony suggests looking at the title of the memo first. Why might the title be helpful?
answers:
It often highlights the main topic or idea of the memo. 

It lists all the people who are involved in the project. 

It contains greetings and closing remarks.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: Based on the conversation, what are some examples of detective questions Bryan could ask himself to understand the memo better?
answers:
Who, What, When (e.g., Who changed the deadline, What is the new deadline, When is the project due?) 

What is the best color scheme for the project presentation? 

Does the company have a cafeteria with good food options?

params.text: Identify And Extract The Ideas Giving Meaning To The Text
Please listen to the conversation between Bryan and Anthony, and answer the questions below:
Bryan:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text:
Bryan: Hey Anthony, I just finished reading this memo about a new project deadline, but I'm not sure what the most important points are.

Anthony: Ah, that can happen! The key is to act like a detective and gather clues. First, look at the title - that's usually a big giveaway.

Bryan: Right, the title is "Revised Deadline for Project Phoenix."

Anthony: Exactly! So, the main idea is about a change in deadline for a project called "Phoenix." Now, try the detective questions: Who, What, When...

Bryan: Okay, well, it doesn't say who in the memo, but "What" is definitely the new deadline. Maybe "When" is mentioned somewhere...

Anthony: There you go! Keep searching, and see if the memo mentions why the deadline changed. That could be another important point.

Bryan: Thanks, Anthony! This detective work seems to be helping already.
Dialogue Text:
Anthony:

choices.question:
Question 1 of 3: The email title is "New Company Policy: Expense Report Procedures."
What is the most likely main idea of the email?
answers:
An explanation of the new rules for submitting expense reports. 

An announcement about a company picnic and its location. 

An introduction of a new software program for employee time management.

choices.question:
Question 2 of 3: You're reading the email and see the sentence in bold: "The deadline for submitting expense reports is now the 15th of each month."
What can you guess about this sentence?
answers:
It's highlighting an important change in the expense report policy.  

It's mentioning an optional step in the expense report process.  

It's introducing a new benefit for employees

choices.question:
Question 3 of 3: You've finished reading the email but are unsure about the specific steps for submitting expense reports.
What can you do to find this information?
answers:
Search online for general expense report procedures.    

Ask your manager a clarifying question about the steps in the email.

Ignore this information and hope you figure it out later.

params.text: What Would You Say? Quiz
Imagine you're reading an email from your manager about a new company policy on expense reports. Use your detective skills to answer the following questions!
Module Summary Quiz
Read each question carefully and choose the BEST answer.

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: You're skimming a short text about healthy eating. What is the BEST way to quickly find keywords related to this topic?
answers:
Scan for titles, headings, bold words, and first sentences of paragraphs.  

Read every sentence carefully from beginning to end.  

Look for long and complicated words you might not understand.

choices.question:
Question 2 of 6: You see the word "nutrition" in a text about food. You don't remember its exact meaning, but you speak French and know the word "nutritionnel" means "related to food."
What strategy are you using to (potentially) understand the meaning of "nutrition"?
answers:
Recognizing transparent words based on similarities with another language.  

Memorizing a definition from a dictionary.  

Skipping the word and hoping you understand the text anyway.

choices.question:
Question 3 of 6: You're reading a report about sales figures. The first sentence says: "Overall, sales increased by 10% in the last quarter."
What can you determine from this sentence about the report?
answers:
It likely focuses on positive sales performance.  

It will explain the reasons why employees are unhappy.  

It introduces a new company policy on customer service.

choices.question: Question 4 of 6: When trying to identify the main idea of a business email, what is the MOST helpful strategy?
answers:
Use detective skills and ask yourself questions like "Who, What, When, Why."  

Focus on the sender's name and greeting at the beginning.  

Read the email very quickly without paying close attention to details.

choices.question: Question 5 of 6: You're reading a company memo about a change in meeting times. The title is "Meeting Schedule Update." What can you predict about the content of the memo?
answers:
It will announce a new company-wide social event

It will explain the reasons behind the change in meeting times.  

It will likely inform you of the new times for upcoming meetings.

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: You finished reading a news article but are unsure about a specific detail. What is the BEST way to clarify your understanding?
answers:
Reread the relevant section of the article to see if you missed any clues.  

Assume you understood everything correctly and move on.  

Ask a friend their opinion on the main idea of the article.
